arcadeHub.title: Arcade
arcadeHub.subtitle: Pick a bonus mini-game to extend your Atom2Univers session.

particules.title: Particles
particules.description: Deflect the quantum particle to earn gacha tickets and Mach3 credits.

metaux.title: Metals
metaux.description: Match alloys in Mach3 mode to forge bonuses and boost production.

wave.title: Photon
wave.description: Become a photon surfing its cosmic wave.

quantum2048.title: Fusion 2048
quantum2048.description: Trigger chain reactions on your chosen grid to reach the requested tile.

sudoku.title: Quantum Sudoku
sudoku.description: Solve freshly generated grids or let the solver reveal a flawless solution.

blackjack.title: Quantum Blackjack
blackjack.description: Face the dealer with an eight-deck shoe that reshuffles as soon as a unique card runs out.

sudoku.title: Quantum Sudoku
sudoku.subtitle: Pick a difficulty, fill the grid and keep track of conflicts as you play.
sudoku.note: Tip: only digits 1–9 are accepted. Validation highlights duplicates in rows, columns and 3×3 boxes. The solver uses backtracking and generation ensures a single-solution puzzle.

blackjack.title: Quantum Blackjack
blackjack.subtitle: Challenge the dealer with an eight-deck shoe that refreshes whenever a unique card runs out.

quantum2048.title: Fusion 2048
quantum2048.subtitle: Pick your grid and merge tiles until you reach the selected goal.

status.ready: Release on the uphill to take off.
status.hold: Hold to dive and build speed.
status.air: Airborne! Aim for the next slope.

table.placeholder: Select an element to display its properties.

fusion.title: Molecular fusion chamber
fusion.intro: Combine your elements to attempt creating brand new molecules. Ingredients are taken from your current stock and success is never guaranteed.

elements.title: Element bonuses

goals.title: Objectives & trophies
goals.intro: Track your galactic achievements and unlock permanent bonuses.
goals.empty: No trophy completed yet. Finish objectives to display them here.

music.title: Music
music.note: Music starts automatically after your first interaction.

brickSkin.title: Brick skins
brickSkin.note: Unlock the “Rush to a Million” trophy to customize your bricks.

status.trackNotFound: Unable to locate the selected track.

usage.title: MIDI programs in use

devkit.title: Quantum DevKit
devkit.intro: Cheat tools for rapid experimentation. Changes apply instantly.

modes.title: Persistent modes
modes.note: Modes remain active while the session stays open (shortcut F9).

devkit.footer: Press F9 to open or close the DevKit.

freeElectrons.name: Free Electrons
freeElectrons.description: Channel electrons to boost every quantum click.

physicsLab.name: Physics Laboratory

particleAccelerator.name: Particle Accelerator
particleAccelerator.description: Boost your particles to intensify passive output.

supercomputer.name: Supercomputers

interstellarProbe.effect: Passive production: +5,000 APS per level. Bonus: with 50+ Free Electrons, every building level adds +100 APC.

starForge.name: Star Forger

multiverseSimulator.name: Multiverse Simulator

realityWeaver.name: Reality Weaver

cosmicArchitect.name: Cosmic Architect

omniverseLibrary.name: Omniverse Library
omniverseLibrary.description: Compile infinite knowledge to boost all output.

quantumOverseer.name: Grand Quantum Overseer
quantumOverseer.description: Order the multiverse and reach singularity.

welcomeCard.title: Welcome
welcomeCard.intro: Welcome to Atom to Univers. Start by clicking to earn Atoms (APC Atoms Per Click), purchase upgrades in the shop, and automate harvesting (APS Atoms Per Second). Unlock mini-games as you progress. The goal is to gather as many Atoms as possible to forge a Universe. Large values use an easy scientific-style notation: 1.0e6 means 1,000,000 (1.0 × 10^6) and the number after “e” tells you how many zeros follow.

particles.label: Particles mini-game:
particles.description: Collide elementary particles to earn draw tickets for the Gacha and credits for the Mach3 mini-game.

gacha.label: Gacha:
gacha.description: Spend your tickets to obtain atoms from the periodic table; completing collections grants APS and APC bonuses among others.

match3.label: Mach3 mini-game:
match3.description: A Match 3 game—line up Copper, Bronze, Silver, Gold, and Carbon (Diamond) as quickly as possible before the timer hits 0. Higher scores mean higher APS production bonuses.

brickSkin.unlocked: Choose the appearance of Particles bricks.

devkit.elementsAdded: DevKit: {count} elements added to the collection!

shop.milestoneHint: Keep exploring ever larger orders of magnitude!

alloyMastery.name: Alloy Mastery

hydrogen.name: Hydrogen (H₂)
hydrogen.description: Combine 2 Hydrogen atoms to create a dihydrogen molecule.

nitrogen.name: Nitrogen (N₂)
nitrogen.description: Merge 2 Nitrogen atoms to form dinitrogen.

oxygen.name: Oxygen (O₂)
oxygen.description: Assemble 2 Oxygen atoms to produce dioxygen.

fluorine.name: Fluorine (F₂)
fluorine.description: Fuse 2 Fluorine atoms to generate a difluorine molecule.

chlorine.name: Chlorine (Cl₂)
chlorine.description: Pair 2 Chlorine atoms to obtain dichlorine.

bromine.name: Bromine (Br₂)
bromine.description: Combine 2 Bromine atoms to produce dibromine.

iodine.name: Iodine (I₂)
iodine.description: Assemble 2 Iodine atoms to create diiodine.

sulfur.name: Sulfur (S₈)
sulfur.description: Gather 8 Sulfur atoms to form an S₈ crown.

phosphorus.name: Phosphorus (P₄)
phosphorus.description: Fuse 4 Phosphorus atoms to synthesize tetraphosphorus.

water.name: Water molecule (H₂O)
water.description: Combine 2 Hydrogens and 1 Oxygen to try forming water.

sodiumChloride.name: Sodium chloride (NaCl)
sodiumChloride.description: Combine Sodium and Chlorine to crystallize salt.

siliconDioxide.name: Silicon dioxide (SiO₂)
siliconDioxide.description: Pair Silicon and Oxygen to obtain quartz.

bronzeAlloy.name: Bronze (Cu-Sn alloy)
bronzeAlloy.description: Blend ~88% Copper with ~12% Tin to craft a protohistoric bronze.

stainlessSteel18_8.name: Stainless steel 18/8
stainlessSteel18_8.description: Mix ~70% Iron, ~18% Chromium, and ~8% Nickel to forge 18/8 stainless steel.

duraluminAlloy.name: Duralumin (Al-Cu-Mn alloy)
duraluminAlloy.description: Assemble ~95% Aluminum with ~4% Copper and traces of Manganese/Magnesium (~1%).

laitonAlloy.name: Brass (Cu-Zn alloy)
laitonAlloy.description: Mix ~65% Copper and ~35% Zinc to shape plumbing brass.

leadAcidAlloy.name: Lead-acid alloy
leadAcidAlloy.description: Solidify ~93% Lead with ~7% Antimony for lead-acid batteries.

ti6Al4VAlloy.name: Ti-6Al-4V alloy
ti6Al4VAlloy.description: Fuse ~90% Titanium with ~6% Aluminum and ~4% Vanadium for aerospace use.

roseGoldAlloy.name: Rose gold (Au-Cu-Ag alloy)
roseGoldAlloy.description: Alloy ~75% Gold, ~22% Copper, and ~3% Silver for an 18-karat rose hue.

platinumIridiumAlloy.name: Platinum-iridium alloy
platinumIridiumAlloy.description: Combine ~70% Platinum with ~30% Iridium for a metrology reference.

details.summary: Number 1 in the periodic table, hydrogen is the simplest and most abundant element in the universe.
paragraphs: A single proton, a single electron: it's hard to be more minimalist. Yet behind that simplicity lies a fundamental role. Hydrogen is the basic building block of matter, the fuel of stars, and one of the constituents of the water that flows on Earth. Invisible, colorless, and highly flammable, it is discreet in appearance but omnipresent in reality.

Hydrogen was born almost at the same time as the universe itself. Right after the Big Bang, about 13.8 billion years ago, matter organized primarily into hydrogen and helium. Even today, hydrogen accounts for about 75% of the baryonic mass of the universe. In stars, it is the fuel of nuclear fusion: four hydrogen atoms merge to form a helium nucleus, releasing the energy that makes the Sun and every star in the Milky Way shine.

On Earth, hydrogen rarely exists in pure form (H₂) because its lightness lets it escape the atmosphere with ease. We mostly find it combined with other elements: in water (H₂O), in hydrocarbons (oil, natural gas), or in the organic molecules that make up living beings. It circulates through the biosphere, geosphere, and hydrosphere as an inseparable companion to carbon and oxygen.

Hydrogen has countless applications. Historically, it inflated the first balloons and airships—until its high flammability made it infamous, as during the Hindenburg disaster in 1937. Today it is a key reagent in the chemical industry (producing ammonia for fertilizers, hydrogenating oils). And tomorrow? It is seen as a serious candidate for clean energy: fuel cells transform hydrogen into electricity while emitting only water.

It is impossible to talk about hydrogen without mentioning water, H₂O, which covers 70% of our planet. It also sits at the heart of hydrocarbons (methane CH₄, gasoline, petroleum) and thus of the energy that powers our societies. In organic chemistry it is everywhere, attached to the carbon framework of our proteins, lipids, and sugars. In short, hydrogen is a universal companion, slipping into almost every molecule that matters for life and for our technologies.

Born from the Big Bang, burned by stars, omnipresent in our cells: hydrogen is the common thread of matter and energy. It is the smallest of the elements, but without it there would be no water, no stars, no life. In short, it is the invisible giant supporting the entire edifice of the cosmos and of our daily lives.

details.summary: Second on the periodic table, helium is an exceptionally light and remarkably stable noble gas.
paragraphs: Symbol "He", atomic number 2: helium is the second element of the periodic table and the second most abundant in the universe. As a noble gas—colorless, odorless, and tasteless—it stands out for its lightness and chemical stability. Unlike its neighbor hydrogen, it dislikes reacting; it prefers to float quietly, indifferent to chemical squabbles. The result is a discreet element, rare on Earth yet essential in the cosmos.

Helium has a dual origin. Much of it was forged during the first minutes after the Big Bang, in primordial nucleosynthesis alongside hydrogen. Since then it has continued to form in the hearts of stars as the product of hydrogen fusion. When four protons join together, they create a helium nucleus and release an enormous amount of energy. In other words, every ray of sunlight we receive is a bill of light paid for with hydrogen transformed into helium.

On Earth, helium is scarce in the atmosphere because its low mass allows it to escape into space. Most of the reserves we can exploit come from deep geological layers, where helium is produced by the radioactive decay of heavy elements such as uranium and thorium. The gas accumulates in underground pockets, often mixed with natural gas, from which it is extracted for our scientific and technical needs.

Helium has found uses that go far beyond party balloons. In cryogenics it is indispensable for cooling superconducting magnets, such as those in MRI scanners or particle accelerators. Its low density and non-flammability make it a safer substitute for hydrogen in modern airships. It also appears in breathing mixtures for deep diving, where it reduces risks linked to nitrogen. In short, this light gas delivers heavyweight applications.

Here is a special case: helium is a noble gas, so it resists bonding. Unlike oxygen or hydrogen, it stays solitary—no stable molecules bear its name, or almost none. The rare helium compounds known, such as the HeH⁺ ion, are observed mostly in laboratories or in interstellar space, not in everyday life. This lack of attachment makes it a chemically unique element: the eternal loner of chemistry.

From the great forge of the Big Bang to the underground pockets of our planet, helium tells both a cosmic and terrestrial story. Its lightness sends it skyward, its stability makes it elusive, yet its usefulness is immense. Whether cooling scientific machines or floating inside a colorful balloon, it reminds us that even the quietest elements hold an essential place in our universe.

details.summary: Symbol "Li", atomic number 3: lithium is a lightweight, silvery, and highly reactive alkali metal.
paragraphs: Symbol "Li", atomic number 3, lithium is a small alkali metal—silvery, featherlight, yet lively as a will-o'-the-wisp. It is the lightest of all metals, so light it floats on water. In nature it never appears pure: too unstable, it prefers to hide inside minerals or brines. Yet this discreet element has become one of the stars of 21st-century life, powering our phones, computers, and electric cars.

Lithium has a peculiar history. A small fraction formed right after the Big Bang alongside hydrogen and helium, but in far lower quantities. Since then its abundance has remained low because it is fragile: stellar reactions tend to destroy it rather than create it. A few cosmic processes—cosmic-ray collisions or particular stages of stellar evolution—still forge some. The result is that lithium is much rarer than its neighbors in the universe, a fact that continues to intrigue astrophysicists.

On Earth, lithium does not appear in pure metallic deposits; it is found mainly in minerals such as spodumene and petalite or in the concentrated brines of salt deserts, especially in South America. It is relatively rare in the crust yet not impossible to find, concentrating in specific geological environments and in the oceans. Long relegated to laboratory curiosity, it is now a strategic resource sought after for energy and technology.

Lithium rose to fame thanks to the rechargeable batteries that bear its name. Light and highly electropositive, it stores and releases energy with great efficiency, making it the central element in our smartphones, laptops, and electric vehicles. Its uses do not stop there. Industry relies on it to craft ceramics and specialty glass. In medicine, certain lithium salts are mood stabilizers, particularly in treating bipolar disorder. It also features in nuclear applications and as an additive in lubricating greases.

Lithium favors simple yet useful combinations. Its salts—lithium carbonate (Li₂CO₃), lithium hydroxide (LiOH), lithium chloride (LiCl)—are the most common. They serve medical, industrial, or energy applications. In batteries, lithium oxides and compounds such as LiCoO₂ or LiFePO₄ take center stage, enabling lithium ions to shuttle back and forth between electrodes.

Born in the universe’s earliest instants yet rare and fragile, lithium has found a second life on Earth as a precious resource. From 19th-century laboratories to 21st-century batteries, it shows how a discreet element can become a pillar of modernity. Tiny in appearance, this metal now carries a significant share of humanity’s energy future on its ions.

details.summary: A light yet exceptionally stiff alkaline earth metal, beryllium pairs rarity, strength, and X-ray transparency, making it a prized material for cutting-edge technologies.
paragraphs: With symbol "Be" and atomic number 4, beryllium is a steel-gray metal that is light but extremely rigid. It belongs to the alkaline earth metals alongside magnesium and calcium. Rare and discreet in daily life, it combines low mass, strength, and transparency to X-rays, which has made it valuable for highly specialized fields.

Beryllium has a singular story in the cosmos. Unlike hydrogen, helium, or even lithium, it was not produced in significant quantities during the Big Bang. Inside stars it is so fragile that fusion destroys it quickly, so its main origin is cosmic spallation, when energetic cosmic rays shatter carbon and oxygen nuclei to create lighter elements.

On Earth, beryllium is scarce. It occurs in minerals such as beryl, the source of emeralds and aquamarines. It is not found in native form because it readily reacts with oxygen and silicon to form very stable minerals, limiting its presence to a tiny fraction of the crust yet enough to supply specialized uses.

Beryllium is chosen where its unique properties are indispensable. Its rigidity and lightness make it a material of choice for aeronautics, aerospace, and certain defense equipment. Transparent to X-rays, it serves as a window in X-ray tubes and scientific instruments, and when alloyed with copper it yields a conductive yet resilient material for demanding electrical components. Its use is nonetheless constrained by the toxicity of its dust, which can cause chronic berylliosis.

Beryllium mainly forms simple ionic or covalent compounds. Beryllium oxide (BeO) is a prized ceramic thanks to its combination of thermal conductivity and electrical insulation. Beryllium chloride (BeCl₂) and beryllium fluoride (BeF₂) are chemical intermediates, while its association with aluminum and silicon in beryl produces gemstones.

Rare, fragile within stars yet robust in our technologies, beryllium is a paradoxical element. Born of cosmic collisions and discreet in terrestrial minerals, it has earned an essential place in cutting-edge instruments. Behind sparkling gems and space components stands this singular metal, proof that even the rarest elements find their role in the story of matter.

details.summary: A discreet yet versatile metalloid, boron pairs rarity and hardness with a rich chemistry that links everyday life to cutting-edge technologies.
paragraphs: Symbol "B" and atomic number 5, boron is a metalloid: not quite a metal, not quite a nonmetal, but a hybrid element with unique properties. As a pure substance it is a blackish or brown solid that is hard, light, and scarce. Yet its compounds, called borates, slip in everywhere: in heat-resistant glass, in detergents, in fertilizers, and even in certain biological reactions. A discreet element with astonishing versatility.

Like beryllium, boron was not produced in significant amounts during the Big Bang, and it is too fragile to survive the nuclear reactions that power stellar cores. Its main cosmic origin is spallation: cosmic rays strike nuclei of carbon, nitrogen, or oxygen and fragment them into lighter elements such as lithium, beryllium, and boron. Boron was therefore born not in stellar furnaces but in the great collisions of interstellar particles.

On Earth, boron is relatively rare. It concentrates chiefly in deposits of borates formed in arid, salt-rich environments such as evaporated lakes. The largest known reserves lie in Turkey, the United States (California), and South America. Although it accounts for only a tiny fraction of the Earth's crust, it has long been accessible and mined for its interesting chemical properties.

Boron and its compounds have many practical uses. In borosilicate glass (as in Pyrex) it brings remarkable resistance to heat and thermal shock. In detergents, borates act as cleaning and disinfecting agents. In agriculture, boron is an essential trace element: plants need it to grow, even in small amounts. In high-tech industry it helps produce ultra-resilient materials such as boron carbide—one of the hardest known solids—and high-performance magnets based on neodymium-iron-boron alloys.

Boron compounds are numerous and varied. Boric acid (H₃BO₃) is used as a mild antiseptic or as an industrial additive. Borates such as borax (Na₂B₄O₇·10H₂O) appear in detergents, enamels, and many chemical applications. In materials science, boron carbide (B₄C) is prized for its exceptional hardness, serving in body armor and nuclear shielding. Modern chemistry also relies on organoboron compounds, which play a central role in synthesizing new molecules, particularly for pharmaceuticals.

Born from cosmic rays rather than stars, rare yet indispensable, boron is an element that keeps a low profile. From kitchen glassware to advanced materials and plant growth, it bridges everyday chemistry and high technology. This hybrid metalloid perfectly illustrates how so-called minor elements can have a major impact.

details.summary: An element of contrasts, carbon links diamonds and graphite, the living cycle and modern industries, by building the immense diversity of organic chemistry.
paragraphs: Symbol "C" and atomic number 6, carbon is the element of contrasts: as much the soft black of graphite as the transparent near-indestructibility of diamond. It forms the backbone of all organic chemistry, the molecular skeleton of living beings. Modest on the periodic table, it nonetheless stands at the heart of life, industry, and even stars: without carbon, no complex molecules, no biology, no humanity.

Carbon did not form during the Big Bang: the young universe produced only hydrogen, helium, and a little lithium. Carbon was forged later inside stars through nuclear fusion. The key mechanism is the triple-alpha process, in which three helium nuclei fuse to create a carbon nucleus. When massive stars die and explode as supernovae, they disperse this carbon into space, enriching the interstellar clouds that spawned planets and, ultimately, the chemistry of life.

On Earth, carbon takes countless forms. In elemental form it appears as graphite—pencil lead and natural lubricant—or as diamond, a crystal of unrivaled hardness. Combined with other elements it is everywhere: in atmospheric carbon dioxide, in carbonate rocks, in subsurface hydrocarbons, and above all in the organic molecules that make up living organisms. This ubiquitous element cycles continuously among atmosphere, oceans, soils, and living beings as part of the carbon cycle.

Carbon has as many uses as it has faces. As graphite it serves in electrodes, batteries, and as a lubricant. As diamond it shines in jewelry yet also excels as an industrial material for cutting and polishing. Spun into carbon fibers it reinforces our most advanced materials. Its compounds are equally diverse: carbon monoxide (CO) as a reducing agent in steelmaking, hydrocarbons as energy sources, and the entire realm of organic chemistry underpinning plastics, medicines, and countless other materials.

Carbon is the most sociable element on the table: with its four available bonds it builds infinite molecular architectures. Methane (CH₄) is the simplest example, but the great organic families showcase its creativity—proteins, sugars, lipids, DNA, every building block of life rests on a carbon framework. It also pairs with minerals, from calcium carbonate (CaCO₃) in limestone and shells to carbon dioxide (CO₂) in the air. Carbon is both the basis of life and a cornerstone of geology.

Carbon is far more than an element: it is the connecting thread between stars and life. Born in stellar furnaces, it settled on Earth to become diamond and graphite, rock and molecule, the skeleton of all biology. Within the simplicity of its four bonds hides an infinite wealth of combinations that make it the architect of living matter. With every breath and every movement, we express a little of this ancient cosmic traveler.

details.summary: A discreet yet omnipresent gas, nitrogen dominates our atmosphere and links soil fertility with the explosive power of chemistry.
paragraphs: Symbol "N" and atomic number 7, nitrogen is a colorless, odorless gas that makes up nearly 78% of the air we breathe. Essential to life, it forms the backbone of proteins and DNA while remaining stable enough to pass unnoticed in everyday life.

Born in intermediate-mass stars, nitrogen results from fusion cycles that transform carbon and oxygen. When these stars die, they release nitrogen into interstellar space, enriching the gas and dust clouds that will eventually form new planets.

On Earth, nitrogen appears mostly as molecular N₂, a molecule with a very stable triple bond. Only specialized bacteria can break it to fix nitrogen into plant-accessible compounds, powering the nitrogen cycle that links air, soils, waters, and living organisms.

As a gas, nitrogen provides an inert atmosphere that shields materials and food from oxidation, while liquid nitrogen is indispensable in cryogenics. Above all, its compounds—from Haber-Bosch fertilizers to explosives like nitroglycerin and TNT—show its ambivalence between nourishing and destroying.

A master of strong bonds, nitrogen is found in ammonia (NH₃), nitrates (NO₃⁻), nitrogen oxides (NO, NO₂), and at the heart of amino acids. Omnipresent yet discreet, it weaves a constant link between air, life, and the most powerful chemical reactions.

Ubiquitous but low-key, nitrogen is both the invisible framework of our atmosphere and a vital building block of biology, reminding us that context decides whether it feeds fields or fuels explosive chemistry.

details.summary: A life-sustaining gas forged in the stars, oxygen powers our breathing, our flames, and countless industrial uses.
paragraphs: Invisible to the naked eye yet indispensable to life, oxygen (symbol "O", atomic number 8) fuels lungs, flames, and industries. Modest on the periodic table, it nevertheless underpins every breath and a multitude of chemical reactions.

Forged in massive stars by the fusion of helium, oxygen was dispersed through space when those stars exploded as supernovae, long before Earth was born. Those enriched cosmic clouds prepared the chemistry of our future blue planet.

Atmospheric dioxygen emerged only with the photosynthesis of cyanobacteria during the Great Oxidation Event. That upheaval enabled the rise of respiration, giving certain organisms—including our cellular ancestors—a new source of energy.

Today oxygen is everywhere: it supports assisted breathing in medicine, intensifies the flames of steelmaking, accompanies divers and astronauts, and stands at the heart of every spectacular combustion.

Always in good company, oxygen forms major molecules: O₂ for our respiration, O₃ for atmospheric protection, H₂O for the water of life, CO as an industrial hazard, and CO₂ as a resource for plants. Allies or threats, these compounds showcase its versatility.

From stellar furnaces to primordial oceans, oxygen embodies the bond between the universe and terrestrial life: a cosmic breath turned vital breath, reminding us that each inhalation echoes the stars.
